loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en: Rosalie M. is from the village of Boundary, Sapang Dalaga, Mis. Occ. She is 29 years old, married, and has a school-aged child. Rosalie owns and operates a specialized retail store, primarily selling dried goods in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Rosalie joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from PMPC. Rosalie is requesting a new loan of 40,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new equipment and tools to expand her business. This loan will be her 2nd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new equipment and tools to expand the business

loans.name: Matluba

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
     Матлуба женщина средних лет, ей 48 лет. Замужем и мать 3-х детей. Занимается продажей женской детской одежды на рынке Фаровон города Гафурова. Матлуба закупает товар из оптового рынка города Истаравшен, она ездит за товаром 2-3 раза в месяц, а иногда ей привозят товар её соседи по бизнесу, чтобы она не тратила лишние деньги на дорогу. Но сейчас она хочет съездить за товаром сама и привезти партию мальчиковой и девичьей школьной формы. Для этого она просит новый займ.
texts.en:
Matluba is a middle-aged woman; she is 48 years old. She is married and has 3 children. She sells women's and children's clothing at the Farovon market in the city of Gafurov. Matluba buys her merchandise at a wholesale market in the city of Istaravshan. She goes there 2-3 times per month, but sometimes her store neighbors bring the merchandise for her, so that she would not waste money for the road. However, now Matluba wants to get the merchandise by herself and bring in a stock of boys' and girls' school uniforms. She is requesting a new loan for this purpose.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of school uniforms

loans.name: Rosa Victoria

texts.es:
La señora Rosa Victoria, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Los Eucaliptos”,  Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es Soltera, tiene 40 años, 03 hijos; que aun dependen de ella y están estudiando.

Su espíritu  luchador que siempre le ha caracterizado y las ganas de salir adelante con sus propios medios le ha valido para iniciar su propio negocio de venta de abarrotes en muy pequeña cantidad y poco a poco fue ganando experiencia en este tipo de actividad y haciéndose muy conocida y querida entre sus clientes.  

En la actualidad tiene una clientela ya fidelizada que a diario acude a su tienda a comprar donde cuenta con todo lo necesario que el ama de casa necesita y es ella quien personalmente les atiende  con el carisma que le caracteriza. 

Con este préstamo de S/ 1,000.00, comprará arroz y azúcar en sacos, fideos en paquetes, leche y conservas de pescado en cajas y en variedad de marcas, utensilios de aseo para el hogar y de higiene personal para continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. 

Rosa Victoria, se siente con mucha fortaleza para continuar trabajando y seguir adelante y asegurar un buen futuro para sus hijos, y  agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  con el cumplimiento de sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
Señora Rosa Victoria belongs to the “Los Eucaliptos” Community Bank in the district of Tarapoto, San Martín province, San Martín department. She is single, 40 years old, and has three children whom she still supports. They are students. Rosa Victoria is characterized by a determined spirit. Her desire to get ahead through her own efforts has helped her start her own business selling groceries in small quantities. She gradually got experienced in this kind of work becoming well-known and well-liked by her customers. She now has a regular clientele who visit her store daily to buy whatever a housewife needs. Rosa Victoria serves them herself with her characteristic charisma. With this S/. 1,000 loan, she will buy rice, bags of sugar, packets of noodles, different brands of milk and canned fish, cleaning utensils for the home, and personal hygiene products so that she can continue to provide good service to her customers. Rosa Victoria feels strong and wants to continue working and making progress in her life. She wants to provide her children with a good future, and is grateful to the Manuela Ramos organisation for helping her realise her dreams and goals.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy groceries for her store

loans.name: Taleb

texts.en:
Taleb is a 48 year old man who lives in Beirut, capital of Lebanon. Taleb has owned bakery since 2004. He does “saj”and “mankoucheh”. The “saj” is the metal oven where you do the saj bread and the saj bread is a traditional Lebanese cooking dome used to make Markouk (“thinned”) bread and doughy confections or Mankoucheh. A mankoucheh looks like a folded pizza, most common toppings are zaatar (thyme), jebneh (cheese) and lahm bi ajin (minced meat). You can eat it anytime of the day, but somehow it tastes better in the morning. Taleb requested a loan of 1500 US dollars from Al Majmoua in order to purchase raw material for his bakery. This is his second cycle and he has always paid on time.  
His previous loan helped him improve his bakery. Taleb is special in his work because he knows how to treat his clients and does good mankoucheh. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. He decided on doing his business because of his experience. In the future, he plans on expanding his business.

loans.use: To purchase raw material for his bakery.

loans.name: Sorn

texts.en:
Sorn Y. is married with a school-aged child. She lives with her husband in Kampong Chnang Province.

Y. is engaged in the business of selling dessert in a local market, typically earning US$1.50 per day. Her husband is a soldier in the province, earning an income of US$2 per day. Both of them have to work hard every day to ensure a good living for their family and for their child.

Therefore, Y. is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US$350 to purchase a calf to raise and sell. By doing so, she believes that she will be able to generate a good standard of living for her family.

loans.use: To buy a calf to raise and sell

loans.name: Susana

texts.es:
Susana es socia del Banco Comunal Las Margaritas.
Susana es casada, tiene 50 años y 8 hijos, Susana se dedica al reciclaje D. botellas D. plástico, papeles, latas, productos que venD. a los intermediarios.
Susana necesita un préstamo D. 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. botellas.
Los sueños D. Susana son que sus hijos salgan adelante y estudien.
texts.en:
Susana is a partner of the Banco Comunal Las Margaritas. She is married, 50 years old, and has 8 children. She makes a living by recycling plastic bottles, paper, and cans, products that she sells to intermediaries. Susana needs a loan of 1,000 soles, which will be invested in the purchase of bottles. Her dream is for her children to get ahead in life and study.

Translated from Spanish by Mark Broscoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of bottles.

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en:
Yaa is 32 years old. She is married with four children, and currently, all her children are in school. Yaa enjoys sales, the business through which she makes money to support her family. She works very hard with the passion of providing brighter future opportunities for her children. She is a petty trader who has been selling bananas and local salt for ten years now.

Yaa buys bananas from villages and retails them to her customers at a profit. With the loan, she wants to inject more capital into her business to buy stock in bulk.

Being able to buy in bulk is advantageous because it is a hedge against price hikes and also helps avoid frequent travel to fill demand. She hopes to use part of her profit to finance the education of her children.

loans.use: To purchase banana and salt in bulk.

loans.name: Nakabiri

texts.en: Nakabiri O. is thirty-two years old. She is a single mother of three children and also has three dependants that she takes care of. She has a retail grocery shop which she has been running for over three years. Nakabiri is using the loan purposely to purchase more retail stock, that is to say salt, sugar, soap, tea leaves, etc for business expansion. Her dream is to become the best competitor in the town of Kalisizo  and earn more profits to educate her children to greater heights.

loans.use: Supplies for business expansion (sugar, maize flour, rice, crates of sodas and so forth).

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase vegetables to sell & chickens for his wife's business

loans.name: Darlinda

texts.en:
Darlinda C. is from the village of Lilo-an Bonifacio, Misamis Occ. She is 54 years old. Darlinda is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Darlinda owns & operates a generalized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products and 'sari-sari' products in the local community. Darlinda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 6500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Darlinda joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Darlinda is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Darlinda from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Hannah

texts.en: Hannah is fifty-two years old. She is divorced and has given birth to one child who goes to school. She lives with her son in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Hannah is a trader. She trades in cosmetics. She hawks locally and treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. She has been in business for thirteen years and wants to expand her business. Hannah needs the loan to procure many kinds of cosmetics – body sprays, creams, pomade, etc. in bulk.

loans.use: To buy cosmetics in bulk

loans.name: Sandra Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Sandra de 52 años de edad,  casada, y con dos hijos, vive en el barrio la Esperanza, su esposo de profesión músico, durante muchos años ella ha trabajado en servicio domésticos, para apoyar a sus hijos y a su esposo, el cual  gana por las piezas que toca en una rotonda Bello Horizonte en la Capital, pero no le ha ido muy bien las personas ya no quieren pagar dicha cantidad de dinero, los tiempos han cambiado es por eso ella también  se dedica a la venta de cosmético para obtener mejores ingresos, ya que el salario es bajo, con el crédito anterior logro mejorar su casa, y con este préstamo lo que desea hacer es un cuarto para mejorar las condiciones de privacidad para su familia. Daña Sandra desde joven ha trabajado ya que sus padres eran de pocos recursos económicos ha llevado una vida difícil, desde horas temprana sale de su casa para poder ir al trabajo, y llega noche a su casa, ya que sale tarde es por eso a futuro desea dedicarse solo a las ventas de cosmético y ropa para poder gozar mas de su familia como su casa. Para comenzar la obra comprara: piedra, arena, cemento, hierro, zinc, perlines, entre otros. Gracias a estos financiamientos ha mejorado su pequeña vivienda el cual esta sastifecha por que ha logrado sus objetivos.
texts.en:
Sandra, 52, is married with two children and lives in the La Esperanza neighborhood of Managua. She has worked for many years in domestic services. Her earnings have helped support her children and husband, who works a professional musician. Her husband plays music at the Rotunda Bello Horizonte, but this does not pay well. As the times have changed, Sandra started a business selling cosmetics to increase her earnings. With a previous loan, Sandra made improvements to her house. With this loan, she will add a room to give more privacy for her family. Sandra has worked from a young age, as her parents were poor. She has had a difficult life, leaving the house early in the morning to go to work and coming home late. In the future, she would like to dedicate herself only to the sale of cosmetics and clothing to earn more for her family and her house. For this project, she will buy stone, sand, cement, iron, metal roofing, steel beams and other materials. Thanks to these loans, she has improved her house and she is satisfied to have achieved her goals.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction materials such as stone, sand cement, iron, beams, and roofing.

loans.name: Darlena

texts.en: Darlena D. is from the village of Naawan, Misamis Oriental. She is 40 years old. Darlena is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Darlena makes and sells food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Darlena has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Darlena joined HSPFI, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Darlena is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the first loan taken out by Darlena from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Sda Mayeberie Group

texts.en:
Pictured above are teachers of the S.D.A Primary School, in Magburaka, northern Sierra Leone. This school, established by the Seven Days Adventist Mission in 1983, currently has 114 pupils. 

This is the first loan that S.D.A Primary School is accessing from Kiva through SMT. School staff from this institution, like many other schools' staff within SMT’s operational areas, come to SMT to apply for loans. With the help of these loans, they can accomplish certain tasks that they would otherwise be unable to accomplish with their mere salaries. Some can pay school fees for their children; others can use the loan to buy furniture, land or house-building materials; others invest in business. At the end of each month, these teachers can repay the loan out of their monthly salaries. The institution’s bursar is directly responsible for deducting the repayment and pays SMT on their behalf.

Fifty-four-year-old David C. K. is the headmaster at the school. He was born in Makump village, and is married with 7 children. David wants a loan in order to renovate his house and pay school fees for his children.

loans.use: Renovate his house and pay school fees for his children

loans.name: Luzmila

texts.es:
Luzmila, de 30 años, es una madre de familia que siempre ha luchado por salir adelante. Vive en la casa de su suegra, junto a su esposo Fredy de 25 años y su querido hijo Bryan, a quien desea brindar unos buenos estudios.

Los verdes campos del poblado de “Huaracayo” han sido, en la vida de Luzmila, un lugar muy agradable para trabajar. Desde muy pequeña sus padres le enseñaron esta labor y ahora ella tiene sus propias tierras en las que trabaja con mucho esmero y sacrificio.
Lo que más le gusta es cultivas las alverjas y choclos, lleva 20 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es transportar sus cultivos, hasta el lugar donde los vende en el mercado de la ciudad. Con el tiempo, espera poner un pequeño puesto en el mercado, ya que siente que pierde mucho al vender sus productos al por mayor.

Este es el sétimo préstamo de Luzmila con MFP, sabe que tiene la responsabilidad de pagar todas sus cuotas puntualmente y está dispuesta a hacerlo. Dentro su banco comunal siempre está al tanto de todos los acuerdos a los que llegan sus compañeros. Con los quinientos nuevos soles solicitados comprará semillas de alverja, ya que esta menestra se está vendiendo muy bien en el mercado.
texts.en:
Luzmila is 30 years old. She is a mother who has always worked hard to get ahead. She lives in her mother-in-law's house, along with her husband Fredy, age 25, and their beloved son Bryan, whom they hope to provide with a good education. Luzmila has always found the green fields of the village of Huaracayo a very agreeable place to work. Starting when she was very small, her parents taught her how to farm, and now she has her own land, which she cultivates with great dedication and sacrifice. What Luzmila likes most is growing peas and corn. She has been doing this work for 20 years, and she thinks the hardest part is transporting her crops to be sold in the city's market. Someday she hopes to open a small stall in the market herself, since she feels that she loses a lot by selling her products wholesale. This is Luzmila's seventh loan with MFP. She knows she is responsible for making all of her payments on time, and she is ready to do so. Within her communal bank, she is always well-informed about the agreements made by her fellow members. With the five hundred Peruvian new soles she is requesting, she will buy pea seeds, since peas are currently selling very well at the market.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying pea seeds

loans.name: Orilawo Funmi

texts.en:
Funmi, 43, is married with 2 children and lives in Lagos, Nigeria. She is hard working and believes that women need to support men in providing for the family. Funmi is a nurse by profession; she sells drugs and groceries in order to earn additional income. She provides clothing, food and more to assist her husband in running the affairs of the home. Her husband is a civil servant who also works hard to meet his financial responsibilities at home. 

Funmi hopes to expand her business and is requesting a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more drugs and groceries to sell. She promises to repay her loan at the due date. She says a big thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drugs and groceries to sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is 31 years old and married with one child who goes to school. She rears animals to earn a living. She is also employed as a civil servant and therefore earns a monthly salary.  She uses her income to support her family and to educate her child. 

She hopes to open a cosmetics shop and improve her living conditions in the future. Being a member of Faulu Kenya, she has been trained on how to manage her business. This has made her business to grow to a higher level.  

She has requested for a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings from Kiva partner Faulu Kenya to buy animal feeds.

loans.use: To buy animal feeds

loans.name: Rogelio

texts.en:
Rogelio S. Jr. is from the city of Carmen Annex, Ozamiz City. He is 24 years old. Rogelio is single. To make a living, Rogelio provides watch repair shop services to local community members. Rogelio has been engaged in his business for over two years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Rogelio joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services. He wanted to help improve his living situation and increase his ability to engage in business activities. Rogelio is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rogelio from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding his watch repair services business

loans.name: La Rosa De Guadalupe Group

texts.es:
El Banco de Emprendimieto conformado por ocho integrantes los cuales en su gran mayoria son oriundos de las ciudades de Santa Cruz, Oruro y chuquisaca de los 8 clientes 6 tienen negocio propio en la localidad de la  guardia en distintos lugares del mercado de el torno,  todos los socios viven en la zona de la Guardia, cuentan con sus negocios hace vaR. años.

La Sra. MARY es la presidenta del banco se dedica a la venta de ropa, tiene su puesto de venta en el mercado de el Torno se dedica  a esta actividad hace vaR. años, empezo vendiendo poca mercaderia pero con los prestamos de la institucion, crecio y ahora cuenta con un buen capital de trabajo, con el dinero del credito comprara mercaderia de temporada ropa abrigada para la epoca de invierno.

De los 8 integrantes cuentan con casa propia 2,  sus sueños de los socios del  banco de emprendimientos es  llegar a tene sus casitas, empresas y vehiculos todos los socios son Padres de familia y Madre de familias, trabajan duro para sacar adelante a sus familias y poder mejorar la calidad de vida de toda su familia.
texts.en:
This entrepreneurial bank is formed by eight members, most of whom are from the cities of Santa Cruz, Oruro and Chuquisaca. Of the eight members, six have their own business in Guardia, in different areas of the Torno market. All of the members live in the Guardia area, and have had their businesses for several years. Mary is the president of the group and sells clothing from a stall in the Torno market. She has done this activity for several years. She began selling just a little bit of merchandise, but with loans from the institution the business grew, and now she has good working capital. With this loan, she will buy seasonal merchandise, like warm clothing for the winter. Of the eight members, two have their own houses. The bank members dream of having their own homes, companies and vehicles. All of them are heads of household, and they work hard to get their families ahead and to be able to improve the quality of life for their families.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Batjargal

texts.en:
Batjargal B., 52, is a widow who lives with her daughter and two nephews in Hovd province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger (the Mongolian nomadic tent). Her two nephews, ages 11 and 12, attend a local primary school. They have been living together in their current home for 10 years. 

Batjargal operates a bone setting and healing service in her town. She has been operating her business since 2005, and her business has become popular in her own province, as well as in surrounding provinces. Batjargal has greatly expanded her business over the past five years. Initially operating her business from her home, Batjargal has since moved to a formal workspace. Batjargal is an open person and focused on the future. She says, “There is almost no one else providing bone setting and healing services in my province. I have been planning to build another place from which to provide services for four customers with four beds. ” She is requesting a 1,400,000 MNT loan to purchase equipment for her bone settling and healing services.

loans.use: To purchase equipment.

loans.name: Renecer De Ayarmaca Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal de “Renacer de Ayarmaca” está conformado por 10 mujeres y 4 varones responsables, alegres y carismáticos, ellos viven en la comunidad de Ayarmaca del distrito de Chinchero. Ayarmaca es una zona rural como muchas del Perú donde la pobreza extrema y la falta de oportunidades son los principales problemas que atraviesa la población para salir adelante. Aquí los meses junio,  julio y agosto son duros, las noches y las madrugadas el clima es helado.  Chinchero se encuentra a 30 Km. al norte de la ciudad del Cusco y está conformado por la zona urbana, 14 comunidades indígenas y dos asociaciones de productores. La población del distrito que según distintas fuentes supera los 10 mil habitantes aún conserva el trueque como forma tradicional de comercio. La principal actividad económica en Chinchero es la agricultura. Poco más de la mitad de los agricultores se dedica al cultivo de papa principalmente. Además, se cultivan en la zona cereales, tubérculos menores, leguminosos, entre otros. Por el lado de la ganadería, destaca la producción de ovejas y el ganado vacuno, y también de llamas traídas de las punas. Entre sus actividades económicas sobresale el comercio minorista y también brindar servicios como por ejemplos: venta de animales menores, venta de comida, venta de leña, venta de arboles, elaboración de artesanía y servicios de construcción. 

La señora Braulia, tiene 46 años, vive en la comunidad de Ayarmaca, es casada, tiene  4 hijos  y su esposo Rafael trabaja como albañil. Su actividad económica principal de la socia es la crianza de animales menores como por ejemplo cuyes, gallinas, pollos, etc. Su actividad complementaria es la agricultura y ganadería. Braulia requiere el préstamo para comprar más animales menores como por ejemplo cuyes.
texts.en:
The Renacer de Ayamaca Communal Bank is comprised of ten women and four men. They are responsible, happy and charismatic. They live in the Ayarmaca community in the Chinchero district. Ayarmaca is a rural area, like many in Peru, where there is extreme poverty and the lack of opportunities. These are the main problems that the population deals with in order to get ahead. The months of June, July, and August are hard here. It is freezing cold at night and at dawn. Chinchero is 30 kilometers to the north of the city of Cusco. It is comprised of the urban zone, 14 indigenous communities, and two producer associations. According to different sources, the district population is over ten thousand inhabitants. They still barter as a traditional way of doing business. The primary economic activity in Chinchero is agriculture. A little over half of the farmers mainly grow potatoes. They also grow grains, small tubers, vegetables, and other things. In regards to the livestock; sheep, cattle, and llamas brought in from the mountains are notable. The economic activities that stand out are retail businesses and providing services. For example they sell small animals, sell food, sell firewood, sell trees, make handicrafts, and provide construction services. Braulia, age 46, lives in the Ayarmaca community. She is married and has four children. Her husband, Rafael, works as a bricklayer. Her main activity is raising small animal like guinea pigs, hens, and chickens, etc. Her supplemental activity is farming and livestock. Braulia needs the loan to buy more small animals like guinea pigs.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more small animals like guinea pigs

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty B. is from the village of Omonay, Damulog, Bukidnon. She is 50 years old, married, and has nine adult-aged children. To make a living, Betty owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Betty has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2010, Betty joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Betty is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Abdugaffar

texts.ru: Курбонов Абдугаффар проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 48 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Сын зарабатывает строительными работами. Сам Абдугаффар имеет высшее образование, экономист. По профессии проработал 10 лет. Сейчас он занимается животноводством. Откармливает и продает скот. Этим видом бизнеса занимается уже 6 лет. Кредит берет для закупа крупно - рогатого скота. Он хочет увеличить количество скот.
texts.en:
Abdugaffar K. lives in the Shahrituz region. He is 48 years old, married, and has four children. His son does construction work. Abdugaffar has a college degree in economics. He worked in his profession for ten years. Now, he works in animal husbandry. He fattens and sells cattle. He has been doing this for six years. He is taking out a loan to buy cattle. He wants to increase his herd.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cattle

loans.name: Lelebeth

texts.en: Lelebeth C. is from the village of Boundary Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental. She is 35 years old, married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Lelebeth owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. Lelebeth has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Lelebeth joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lelebeth is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lelebeth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future

loans.name: Flor

texts.es: Flor tiene 40 años de edad, vive en compañía de su esposo y su hija en su casa propia. Desde hace 4 años trabaja vendiendo ropa y lo realiza por medio de pedido. Su forma de trabajo consiste en llevar muestras de ropa a la casa de sus vecinas y amigas, para que ella viendo las prendas se anime a comprar uno. Una de abastecerse de esta mercadería, es que cada cierto tiempo viaja hasta los mercados más concurridos de la ciudad de Lima, adquiriendo nuevas prendas con diseños nuevos, modelos que son del agrado de sus clientes. En un futuro ella espera seguir mejorando su negocio pues le agrada mucho realizarlo y ella piensa en que puede resultarle muy bien a futuro. Es su onceavo crédito con MFP y se compromete a ser muy puntual con todos sus pagos. Con el crédito que solicita,  comprará mayor cantidad de prendas y de esa manera sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Flor, 40, lives with her husband and daughter in her own home. For four years she has sold clothing based on prior customer orders. Her method of working is to take samples to show her friends and neighbors so that they might be encouraged to order something once they see the samples. Every so often she travels to the city of Lima to stock up on merchandise; she buys items of current design, styles that her customers like. In the future, she’d like to continue to improve her clothing sales because she enjoys this work very much and feels it could be quite profitable in the future. This is her 11th loan with MFP and she pledges to be very punctual with her repayments. The requested loan will be used to buy more articles of clothing thus increasing her income.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy more articles of clothing in order to increase sales.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more good-quality cosmetics

loans.name: Norma

texts.es: Norma, de 36 años, es una mujer muy alegre y trabajadora, vive en una casa alquilada junto a su esposo Rolando de 42 años y sus 4 hijos menores, a quienes desea brindarles un mejor futuro. Los hermosos campos del poblado natal de Norma, han sido en su vida el lugar que la ha visto crecer y formar su familia, desde muy pequeña sus padres le enseñaron a trabajar en la chacra y ahora ella tiene sus propias tierras en las que trabaja con mucho esmero y sacrificio, es así que pone en práctica todos sus conocimientos con respecto al cultivo y cosecha de espinacas, zanahorias y lechugas. Lleva 10 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es transportar sus cultivos, hasta el lugar donde los vende en el mercado mayorista de Tarma. Con el tiempo, desea comprar nuevas tierras, para incrementar su producción. Este es el primer crédito con MFP, sabe que tiene la responsabilidad de pagar todas sus cuotas puntualmente y está dispuesta a hacerlo. Dentro su banco comunal siempre esta al tanto de todos los acuerdos a los que llegan. Con los mil nuevos soles solicitados, comprará más abono para mejorar sus cultivos.
texts.en:
Norma, 36, is a very cheerful and hardworking woman. She lives in a rented house with her husband, Rolando, 42, and their four young children, for whom she wants to offer a better future. Norma has lived her entire life in the beautiful fields of her native village. She has seen her family form and grow there. From a young age, her parents taught her to work on the farm and now she has her own lands where she works with much dedication and sacrifice. She puts into practice all her knowledge about the cultivation and harvesting of spinach, carrots, and lettuce. It takes 10 years to complete this process and she believes that the most difficult part is to transport the crops to the wholesale market, Tarma, where they are sold. Over time, she would like to buy new land to increase production. This is Norma's first loan with MFP and she knows she has the responsibility to complete all her payments on time and is prepared to do so. Within the community bank, she always keeps herself informed of all the business agreements that the group has reached. With the 1000 soles that she has requested, Norma will buy more fertilizer to improve her crop yields.

Translated from Spanish by Angela Yeh, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for her crops

loans.name: Gracias Morenita Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Gracias Morenita inicia su ciclo 14 con 21 socias.
La señora Julia es por primera vez presidenta D. su Banco Comunal, asume con M. entusiasmo y alegría, lo que mas le agrada D. Finca Perú es el incentivo al ahorro y la facilidad D. los prestamos que le ayudan M. a su negocio.
Julia es casada, tiene 5 hijos y solo 1 esta estudiando. Julia venD. comida especialmente cebiche D. manera ambulatoria al frente D. una institución publica, actividad que realiza desD. las 9 D. la mañana hasta las 12 del mediodía.
Julia necesita un préstamo D. 600 soles para la compra D. aceite, arroz y platos.
Julia tiene una casa D. material rustico y su sueño es construir D. material noble, también le gustaría ampliar su negocio y que su hija sea profesional.
texts.en:
The “Gracias Morenita” communal bank begins its 14th cycle with 21 members. Julia is President of her communal bank for the first time. She takes on the position with enthusiasm and joy. What she likes best about Finca Perú is the savings incentives and the ease of payment terms on the loans that are of great use for her business. Julia is married and has five children only one of whom is in school. She sells food, especially cebiche (marinated fish) in front of a public institution from 9am until noon. Julia needs a 600 sol loan to buy cooking oil, rice and dishes. Julia has a house maD. from rustic materials and her dream is to build with substantial materials. She’d also like to expand her business and that her daughter becomes a professional.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cooking oil, rice and dishes.

loans.name: La Esperanza De Los Pobres Group

texts.es:
El grupo se llama "La esperanza de los pobres" se integra de cuatro señoras, está ubicado en la localidad de Benito Juárez municipio de Copainala estado de Chiapas México, la razón del nombre es porque con este préstamo tienen la esperanza de salir adelante con sus familias.

     La señora que se le tomo la entrevista se llama dilia M. C., es casada, en la cual procreo nueve hijos quienes dos de ellos ya están casados: Blanca Orbelia y Ediel, los demás son: rosilia, adeldamar, Juan Edgar, Eliazar, José Gabriel, Erileni, y el ultimo es Edirsein de doce años que estudia  en la primaria.

    Ella se dedica a su hogar y a la venta de pollos desde hace cuatro años en donde le va bien ya que ha obtenido buenos ingresos en su hogar  y en su familia, aun así también se ha animado de poner una tienda de abarrotes para que con ellos pueda solventar los gastos  que tiene de sus hijos que está estudiando en la universidad.

        Su inspiración por esta actividad fue su familia ya que quiere lo mejor para ellos y busco esta trabajo por sé un negocio bueno que deja buena ganancia  y los pequeños gastos de su hogar.

        Con las ganancias que obtiene de dos actividades  lo invierte comprando más mercancía, así su venta de pollos y abarrotes se encuentre en buen estado y su clientela se anime a consumir su mercancía. 
       Su sueño es que su negocio de pollos a amenté como también tener un local en donde exhiba su mercancía , así con ello obtener más ingreso y seguir apoyando a sus hijos a que terminen una carrera donde ellos puedan depender de sí mismo.

      Los integrantes del grupo son las siguiente y cada una con diferente actividad:

      Dilia M. C.: invierte el préstamo en la compra de rejas de pollos para venderlo aliñado (destazado)  y en pié. 
      Elodia Sánchez A.: invierte el préstamo en la compra de gasolina para su camioneta de transporte.

     Evangelina S. S.: invierte el préstamo en la compra de quesos, como también surtirse con perfumes y ropas  para salir a venderlo en las comunidades.

     Belladina López Córdova: invierte el préstamo en la compra de ingrediente para la elaboración de tamales como también de dulces: de nuégado, coco, de leche entre otros.
texts.en:
The group is called  "La esperanza de los pobres" [The Hope of the Poor] and is made up of four women. It is located in the community of Benito Juárez in the town of Copainala, state of Chiapas, México. The reason for the name is that with this loan they hope to get ahead with their families.  

     The woman who was interviewed is named Dilia M. C.. She is married and has nine children. Two of them are already married: Blanca Orbelia y Ediel. The rest are: Rosilia, Adeldamar, Juan Edgar, Eliazar, José Gabriel, Erileni, and the youngest is Edirsein, twelve years old, who goes to primary school.

    She is a housewife and also has hold sold chicken for four years. It has gone well for her since she has obtained good income for her home and her family. Even so, she has decided to open a grocery store so she can pay her children's university expenses. 

     Her inspiration for this activity was her family, since she wants the best for them and is looking for this work because it is a good business that gives good earnings and little expense for her home.   

        She invests the earnings from both activities in buying more merchandise, so her chicken and grocery sales are doing well and her customers want to consume her merchandise. 
 
       Her dream is for her chicken business to grow and also to have a locale to show her merchandise, as well as have more income and continue to support her children so they can finish their studies and support themselves. .

       The members of the group are the following and each one has a different activity. 

      Dilia M. C.: she will invest the loan in buying chicken to sell in seasoned pieces and in pie. 
 
      Elodia Sánchez A.: she will invest the loan in buying gasoline for her transport truck.
 
     Evangelina S. S.: she will invest the loan ion buying cheeses and also a variety of perfumes and clothing to sell in the communities. 

     Belladina López Córdova: She will invest the loan in buying ingredients for making tamales as well as sweets made from yucca, coconut and milk, among other things.

loans.use: To purchase chicken to sell in seasoned pieces and in pie.

loans.name: María

texts.en:
Maria, 29, lives in the region of Piura in the district of Tambogrande. It is a more humid region of northern Peru which grows a large quantity of mangoes and limes. She lives in her own home along with her partner and their three children.

Maria manages a small general store in the front of her home, selling everything from candy to rice to toilet paper to gifts. She is very well known in the area due to her high quality products and good selection.

This will be her first loan from Edpyme Alternativa with which she hopes to take advantage of bulk discounts and expand her inventory in order to increase her market share. She feels confident about the demand for her products.

One of her greatest dreams is to see her children become professionals and receive good educations. She is dedicated to her family and the success of her business which provides for their well being.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her store

loans.name: Malika Chynybaeva's Group

texts.en:
The southern regions of Kyrgyzstan are very rich in terms of fruits and vegetables. Their generous soil brings millions of tons of fresh crops every year. Dried fruits are very popular too. Rare sorts of fruits give the Kyrgyz government a promising future in exporting food supplies.
Malika C., 23, sells vegetables and fruits at the central market of Tokmok. She is a young mother of a three-year-old child and helps her parents financially. Her husband works at the firm “Stroi Service”. Malika hopes to have a greener future for her family and works hard to improve her business. She has applied for a loan to increase her goods and increase her profits. She and her husband plan to purchase a house and an automobile.
Zarima A., 26, works in a mosque in Tokmok. She is married and has two children. The purpose of her loan is to buy coal for the winter.
Khamrabai J., 25, is involved in a cell-phone business in the market of Tokmok. The purpose of this loan is to buy additional goods and resell them to make a good profit.
Bakhtiyar A., 27, constructs houses and apartments. He plans to start a fruit and vegetable business. This loan will be spent on purchasing goods for starting up his business.

Where did this loan come from?
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan. Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and society as well), Profit (to be profitable in order to grow further), and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video presentation about the organization, please visit: www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135.
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team – Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – at www.kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Canal De Bendicion 1 & 2 Group

texts.es:
Ana es una de los miembros del Grupo Canal de Bendicion 1,2. Grupo cuya mayoria de sus miembros son Dominico - haitiano o emigrantes de Haiti que viven en los bateyes de la Ciudad de Romana, una de las ciudades turistica de Republica Dominicano, con una alta escala de lujo, de donde deriva su economia junto a una de las mas grande industrias de azucar. Su negocio es vender ropas nuevas y usadas, la cual adquiere en los mercados de pulgas ubicados en Santo Domingo o en la frontera con Haiti. Ana es casada y madre de 4 hijos. Nos dice que su reto o desafío más difícil ha sido poder darle una buena educacion a sus hijos.

Ana está muy emocionada de recibir su 1er. préstamo en Esperanza Internacional e invertirlo en su negocio con el cual lleva ya alrededor de 7 años. Está planificando invertir su nuevo préstamo en la compra de varias piezas de ropa nueva y un paquete de ropa usada, para luego verderlas por piezas, utilizara las ganancias de su negocio para reinvertirlo en el mismo. Su sueño es poder expandir su negocio establecido.
texts.en:
Ana is a member of the “Canal de Bendición 1,2” group.  Most of the group's members are Dominican-Haitians or emigrants from Haiti who live in 'bateyes' (company towns where sugar workers live) in the town of Romana, one of the Dominican Republic's tourist destinations which has a high scale of luxury.  This is what the town's economy  is based on, together with one of the biggest sugar factories.  Ana's business is selling new and used clothing.  She acquires her clothing in the flea markets of Santo Domingo or on the border with Haiti.  Ana is married and has 4 children.  She tells us that her biggest challenge is being able to provide her kids with a good eduction.

Ana is very excited to be receiving her first loan from Esperanza Internacional and will invest it in her business which she has had for around 7 years.  She is planning to invest her loan in buying various items of new clothing and a packet of used clothing whose items she will then sell individually.  She will use her profits to re-invest in her business.  Her dream is to be able to expand her established business.

loans.use: To buy new and used clothing

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 32-year-old engaged man from Lebanon.  He lives on his own. He has been working as a taxi driver since 2005. His main service route is between his town and its surroundings. He also takes private transportation such as picnic, traveling etc.  He works hard to earn a profit because he helps his family with the expenses. They live near his house and he is the one who takes care of them. Today he is requesting $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to perform much needed maintenance work on his taxi’s engine and body and to obtain the proper legA. clearance for his vehicle. In the future, he is hopes to purchase a new car so that he can continue to expand his business. He feels positive about his business growth for the coming year.

loans.use: To perform maintenance on his taxi’s engine and body and to obtain legal clearance for his vehicle

loans.name: Jovito

texts.en:
Jovito M. is from the village of Benito, Soliven, Isabela. He is 36 years old. Jovito is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Jovito owns and operates a farm, raising crops.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting corn for sale. Jovito has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 30000 PHP per harvest.

In 2010, Jovito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovito has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from ASKI. Jovito is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jovito from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand the his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Madelyn's Group

texts.en:
Madelyn Y. is from the village of Looc Libertad Sapang Dalaga Mis. Occ. She is 28 years old. Madelyn is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by GDMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Luxurious.

Madelyn is married and has two infant-aged children. To make a living, Madelyn owns & operates a business selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Madelyn has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Madelyn joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Madelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Madelyn is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Madelyn from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Shahri

texts.ru: Абдулхакова Шахри проживает в районе Вахдат. Возраст, 45 лет. Вдова, имеет 5 детей. Образование среднее. Занимается торговлей. У нее имеется магазин, где она продает продукты питания и одежду. Этим видом деятельности занимается 19 лет. В продвижении бизнеса ей помогает её старшая дочь. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en: Shahri A. lives in the Vahdat Region. 45 years of age. A widow with five children. Secondary education. She is a retailer. She keeps a store in which she sells groceries and clothing. She has been in this business for 19 years. Her oldest daughter helps her in the business. She is taking out a loan to increase her saels volume.

loans.use: Increasing sales volume

loans.name: Ben Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BEN de l’association BENKADI II est composé de 6 femmes mariées de la sous préfecture de Yangasso préfecture de SAN région de Ségou (quatrième  région administrative de la république du MALI). Les membres du groupe BEN vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 39 ans et 7 enfants. 
Elles se sont connues à travers le voisinage et la  parenté. Les membres de ce groupe ont intégré le programme de Soro Yiriwaso cette année et sont à leur 1er  cycle. Elles évoluent dans les activités génératrices de revenus il y’ a environ 6 ans et font l’achat vente de condiments et diverses marchandises. 
ASSATA D., la présidente du groupe, qui vend des condiments de tous genres à son domicile, compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 12 paquets de cube maggi, 5 sacs de sel, 6 kg de poivre, ½ kg de laurier,  10 sacs d’oignon, 4 kg de l’ail, 2 sacs de choux, 1 carton de concentrée de tomate. Sa clientèle est généralement constituée de femmes. Elle s’approvisionne à Koutiala pour revendre à Yangasso à son domicile, en détail et en espèce. 
Elle prétend mensuellement à un bénéfice de 23.000FCFA tandis que les autres membres du groupe compte sur un bénéfice de 19.500 FCFA. 
Les membres du groupe BEN compte utiliser leur bénéfice pour   rembourser la dette subvenir aux besoins familiaux et réinvestir dans l’entreprise pour pouvoir l’agrandir.
texts.en:
The BEN group belonging to BENKADI II association is made up of six married women from the "sous-préfecture" of Yangasso, San Prefecture, Ségou region (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The members of the BEN group live in big traditional families. On average, they are aged 39 and have 7 children. 

They know each other because of being neighbors or through kinship ties. The members of this group joined Soro Yiriwaso this year and are on their first loan. They have been involved in money-earning activities for about six years and they buy and sell condiments and various other merchandise. 

ASSATA D., the president of the group, who sells all sorts of condiments out of her home, intends to use her share of the loan to buy 12 boxes of Maggi cubes, 5 sacks of salt, 6 kg of pepper, 1/2 kg of bay leaves, 10 sacks of onions, 4 kg of garlic, 2 sacks of cabbages, and 1 box of tomato concentrate. Her clientele is generally made up of women. She buys her merchandise in Koutiala and sells it in Yangasso out of her home, retail and for cash. 

She says she makes a monthly profit of 23,000 F CFA where as the other members of the group have a profit of 19,500 F CFA. The members of the BEN group intend to use their profit to reimburse the loan, cover family expenses, and reinvest in their businesses so as to expand them.

loans.use: buying condiments for resale

loans.name: Maria Mercedes

texts.es:
La Sra. María Mercedes, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Los Eucaliptos" tiene 38 años. Es Conviviente y es madre de 01 hijo, vive en el Distrito de Tarapoto y Provincia de San Martin. 

María Mercedes se dedica a la Venta de Comidas preparadas por ella misma y lleva varios años en el negocio, se encuentra ubicado en un ambiente muy acondicionado, un lugar muy amplio y acondicionado para atender a sus clientes que diariamente acuden a su local. Nos cuenta que a diario tiene muy buenas ventas,  es conocida y tiene muy buena acogida.   

En la actualidad, continúa con el mismo negocio y esta muy contenta con su trabajo que realiza día a día. Es ella quien personalmente atiende a sus clientes con el carisma y amabilidad que le caracteriza.

Con este crédito  de S/ 1,500.00 Nuevos Soles, comprará ingredientes para la preparación diaria de sus alimentos como, arroz en kilos, aceites en litros, pollos en javas, plátanos , maduros en racimos y también  algunos utensilios, para brindar una mejor atención a sus clientes. 

María Mercedes se siente llena de vida y con ganas de seguir adelante, su sueño es implementar su propio Restaurant.
texts.en:
María Mercedes, 38, is a member of the “Los Eucaliptos” communal bank.  She has a live-in partner and is the mother of a son.  She lives in Tarapoto district, San Martin province.

María Mercedes sells prepared food that she makes herself; she’s been in business several years.  It’s located in a well-equipped, ample and well-conditioned space to take care of her customers who come by daily.  She tells us that her daily sales are good; she’s well known and is well received. She’s still in the same business and is very happy with the work she does day to day.  It is she herself who personally tends to her customers with her characteristic charisma and kindness.

She will use this 1500 new sol loan to buy ingredients for the daily preparation of meals like: rice by the kilo, oil by the liter, cases of chicken, bananas, plantains by the bunch, as well as some utensils to provide better customer service.

María Mercedes feels full of live driven to continue forward.  Her dream is to set up a restaurant of her own.

loans.use: She will buy ingredients to prepare her daily meals as well as some utensils.

loans.name: Khoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Khoeun S. (shown in the photo) asked for a prior Kiva loan. She is now requesting another loan in the amount of $700 to continue her farming business and purchase weaving materials for her daughters' weaving business.

Khoeun and her husband live on an island located 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have eight children--four sons and four daughters. Three are married and live outside the family home; one son is a construction worker; two weave silk at home and the other three attend school.

loans.use: To use for farming and buy weaving materials for her children’s weaving business

loans.name: Reynold

texts.en:
Reynold B. is from the village of Villa Victoria Echague. He is 54 years old, married and has 3 adult-aged children. Reynold owns and operates a farming business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. Reynold has been engaged in his business for over 25 years and earns approximately 30,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2011, Reynold joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Reynold is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Reynold from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Erlina

texts.en:
Erlina is a married woman with four children. She is 35 years old and has had a sari-sari (variety) store for 8 years.

Erlina sells items like sugar, canned goods and soap to the people in her community. Erlina's husband is a fisherman. She helps him by selling all his catch to the market.

Erlina is requesting a loan of 13,000 PHP to to purchase fishing hooks, nets and items to resell such as canned goods.

In the future, she hopes to have all her children finish college.

loans.use: to purchase fishing hooks, nets and items to resell such as canned goods.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: La señora Maria es comerciante de cosméticos y artículos de belleza, lo cual es su principal fuente de ingreso; con el dinero del préstamo comprara material de construcción como ser: arena, cemento, ladrillos ya que Maria desea refaccionar la cocina de la casa donde vive. Vive en casa de un pariente ubicado en la zona Vino Tinto de la ciudad de  La Paz,; está casada y tiene un hijo. Maria se encuentra muy satisfecha con los créditos que se le otorgaron y esta es la segunda vez que el crédito va a través de Kiva.
texts.en: María is a cosmetics and beauty supplies merchant; this is her main source of income.  She will use the money from the loan to buy building materials and supplies like: sand, cement and bricks because María wants to refurbish the kitchen in the house where she lives.  She lives in the house of a relative in the Vino Tinto neighborhood of La Paz.  She’s married and has one son.  María is very satisfied with the loans she was granted and this is the second time the loan is through Kiva.

loans.use: to refurbish her kitchen.

loans.name: Nakyesa Widows Group

texts.en:
M. Moses, 35, operates a butcher shop in Nakyesa-Kayunga. The happily married father of 10 says his business has been in existence for eight years now. 

He was previously a farmer. After his savings had accumulated from the crop sales he made, he decided to try out some other business venture in the form of this butcher shop. 

Weekly, he says, he can make profits to the tune of 150,000 UGX. With this loan, he is going to buy more cow meat  to resell at his butcher shop.

loans.use: to purchase more beef to resell.

loans.name: Huruma Group

texts.en:
Johari, who is in her mid-thirties, is married with three children who are still at school.  She has been selling second hand clothes from door to door for five years now. She works from 10:00am to 6:00pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be Johari's 3rd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to increase on the clothes stock and has paid back her loans successfully.  She hopes for a loan to buy a bale of second hand clothes, so that she will have a good stock of clothes.  Her dream is to one day open a big store where she can sell her clothes.

Johari will share this loan with her loan group "Huruma", which has a total of fifteen members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

In the picture, Johari is standing and holding a baby.

loans.use: to buy a bale of second hand clothes.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie is a 41-year-old married woman living in San Francisco, Agusan Del Sur. Tessie is engaged in farming and has been growing rice for 10 years. She sells her harvest at the market and earns about 3,700 PHP per month from doing this farming.

This loan will be used to purchase seeds, 6 bags of fertilizer, and other farm inputs. In the future, Tessie hopes to buy a bigger farm to support her family.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, 6 bags of fertilizer, and other farm inputs

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 34-year-old married woman from Lebanon. She is living with her husband. In 2005, she started running her own business working as a hairdresser receiving clients at her home. She has worked in this occupation for eight years. With her business income, she is helping to supplement the household income. Today, she is requesting to borrow $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase new hairdressing tools and supplies. She is in real need of getting those materials so that she can improve her business. In the future, she hopes to open a formal beauty salon.

loans.use: to purchase new hairdressing tools and supplies

loans.name: Hokponto

texts.fr: Née en 1959 au Bénin, Hokponto est mariée à un gardien du nom de Oké. Le couple cinq enfants, tous à leur charge. Parmi les enfants, certains sont scolarisés. Hokponto vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Hokponto assure avec son mari les différentes charges de la maison. Hokponto n’a jamais été à l’école. Pour satisfaire ses besoins ainsi que ceux de ses enfants, Hokponto vend des poissons fumés de façon ambulante. Hokponto s’approvisionne dans l’un des marchés du  Bénin. Cette activité lui génère des revenus l’aidant à couvrir les différentes charges de sa famille. Dans l’optique de rehausser davantage le niveau de son activité et d’accroître son profit, Hokponto sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en: Born in 1959 in Benin, Hokponto is married to Oké, a security guard. The couple has five children, all still in their care. Some of the children are in school. Hokponto lives with her husband and children. She provides for the different household needs jointly with her husband. Hokponto never attended school. To  support herself and her children, she sells smoked fish as a street vendor. Hokponto stocks up at a market in Benin. This business brings her an income helping her to cover different family expenses. With the goal of growing her business further and increasing her profits, Hokponto is seeking a new loan from ALIDé.

loans.use: to buy fish

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en:
This borrower is from Iraq. He is 26 years old, married and has two children.

Hussein has owned a generator since 2010.  He distributes power lines for houses. He has more than three years experience, a good reputation and he is well known in his area.

He is requesting a $3000 loan to build a soundproof room for the generator and to purchase additional diesel tanks. He is aiming to gain more profits so he can improve his family’s quality of life.

loans.use: To build a soundproof room for a generator and to purchase additional diesel tanks.

loans.name: Umu

texts.en:
Umu is 23 years old and single with no children. She runs a pharmacy in Lumley, near a neighborhood of Freetown. She takes care of three relatives. 

Umu has been in this business for three years and sells blood tonic, capsules and various types of medicine at her store.  She earns additional income from distributing soft drinks and bundles of water.  She says that the main challenges to her business are expired drugs and increasing shop rent.

She requested this loan through BRAC Sierra Leone to purchase various types of medicines. Umu says that the extra income from this loan will help her increase her savings. In the future, she would like to expand her business to various other districts.

loans.use: To purchase various types of medicines

loans.name: Hachem

texts.en:
Hachem is a 48-year-old married man and the father of four children. He has been working selling coffee and hot drinks since 1994 and is still working hard to improve his business in order to provide his precious family with the best, healthy living.

Hachem loves his family a lot and plans to meet all of their needs. In addition to providing them with the best education, he was able to finish his Intermediate education and was hoping to have a university degree, but life was harsh for him and he had to help with his family's income.

Hachem is planning to expand his business through buying an additional espresso machine through a loan requested from Al Majmoua, a Kiva partner. It's Hachem's first time experiencing Al Majmoua's loans and hopes it will be with positive effect.

Hachem works in a manufacturing city. He doesn't have a coffee shop, but he has a carriage that holds all of his things, and most of the workers look forward to his coffee after hard working hours.

Through the second coffee machine, Hachem can increase his income and fulfill all of his family's dreams and needs, and fulfill his dream of educating his children, too.

loans.use: to buy another espresso machine to increase his business

loans.name: Manuel

texts.es: El señor Manuel es abogado y trabaja en las oficinas legales de la Lotería Nacional y su esposa es comerciante. El crédito lo requiere para la cancelación de una maestría  en Leyes en la universidad Mayor de San Andrés. Vive en casa propia ubicada en la zona de Ciudad de Satélite en la ciudad de El Alto;  es casado   y tiene dos  hijos. Con el crédito que anteriormente se le concedió, también a través de Kiva, pudo hacer el pago inicial de la Maestría que está estudiando; por esta razón está muy agradecido con los financiadotes de Kiva.
texts.en:
Sr. Manuel is an attorney and works at the legal offices of the National Lottery.  His wife is a merchant.  Manuel is requesting this loan so that he can pay for a Masters in Law degree from the Greater University of San Andrés.  He lives in his own home in the District of Ciudad de Satélite in the city of El Alto.  Manuel is married and has two children.  
	
With his previous loan, which was also funded through Kiva, he was able to make the initial payment toward his Masters degree.  For this reason, Manuel is very grateful to the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to pay the second installment toward his Masters degree.

loans.name: Mercedes María

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal María Auxiliadora se reúne en La parroquia Sequita, pertenece a Montecristi prospero cantón manabita, lleno de gente trabajadora dedicada y orgullosa de sus raíces, La Sequita es una parroquia donde sus habitantes son gente honesta que solo saben trabajar y dedicarse a sus familias.

En este lugar vive la señora Mercedes, ella tiene 63 años de edad, hace algunos años su querido esposo falleció y  de esa relación tuvo 13 hijos que fueron su fuerza para seguir adelante, todos sus hijos  ya son mayores de edad pero dos de ellos aun viven  en su casa.

Nuestra amiga para ganarse la vida se dedica a  la venta de ropa de todo tipo,  su forma de venta es puerta a puerta y por pedidos que le realizan sus clientes con anticipación, trabaja tres a cuatro días a la semana en las mañanas ya que es más fresco y también vende en su casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes.  Ella  deja a crédito y cobra cada 8 días. Su mercadería la compra en Quito y Guayaquil ya que dos de sus hijos viven allá y le mandan la ropa cuando necesita.
 
Este crédito lo va emplear en comprar más mercadería como: pantalones, blusas, camisetas y ropa de niños. Está en el Banco Comunal hace 4 años  y le gusta porque  sus compañeras del grupo son muy solidarias y se entretiene en las reuniones. 

Sus sueños son gozar de una vejez muy feliz y tener buena salud.
texts.en:
The  María Auxiliadora communal bank meets in the Sequita parish, part of  Montecristi, in the prosperous Manabita canton.  It is made up of hardworking people who are proud of their roots.  La Sequita is a parish where the people are honest and know how to work and take care of their families.

Mercedes, 63, lives here and some years ago her dear husband passed away.  They had 13 children who were their reason to strive to get ahead.   All of their children are grown now but two still live at home.

To make a living our friend sells all kinds of clothing by going house to house, and also by taking orders that her customers place ahead of time.  She works three or four days a week in the mornings since it is cooler, and she can also sell to her customers from her house. She sells on credit and 
collects once a week.  She buys the merchandise in Quito and Guayaquil since two of her children live there and they send her the clothing when she needs it.

She will use this loan to buy: pants, blouses, shirts and children's clothing.  She has been in the communal bank for 4 years and she likes it because the members are united and they enjoy themselves at the meetings.

Her dreams are to have a happy old age and good health.

loans.use: to buy pants, blouses, shirts and children's clothing

loans.name: Marvin Roberto

texts.es:
Marvín, vive con su esposa  y sus hijos de 16, 18, 20, él se dedica a la agricultura, sembrando maíz y frijol, su esposa es ama de casa y le apoya en las actividades, actualmente se encuentra con la siembra de maíz.
Necesita de un financiamiento para comprar abono, limpiar el terreno y pagar mano de obra, esta será una gran ayuda para Marvín, quien desea tener una cosecha abundante y sana.
El tiene por objetivo dar los cuidados a su familia, trabajar fuertemente por ellos y apoyarlos para que puedan superarse.
texts.en:
Marvín lives with his wife and children aged 16, 28, and 20. He does agricultural work, planting corn and beans. His wife is a homemaker and she helps him with his business. Currently she is helping to plant corn. 

He needs financing to buy fertilizer, to clear the land, and to pay laborers. This will be a great help to Marvín who wants to have an abundant and healthy crop. 

His goal is to help his family, to work hard for them, and to help them so that they can succeed.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, to clear the land, and to pay laborers

loans.name: San Francisco Group

texts.es:
En la ciudad D. Paraguarí, se reunieron un grupo D. mujeres con el fin D.  capitalizar su actividad y otras para emprender actividades productivas, D. ahí que coordinaron una reunión para interiorizarse sobre el programa D. mujeres emprendedoras D. la Fundación, el cual les resultó muy interesante por los beneficios que les otorgaría  el programa. El comité lleva por nombre San Francisco ya que las mismas viven en el barrio del mismo nombre, ellas se han caracterizado por la unidad en el grupo, su dinamismo y respeto mutuo quienes por medio D. este emprendimiento fortalecerán el lazo entre ellas, actualmente se encuentran en el  segundo  ciclo con calificación excelente, integrada por 17 emprendedoras señoras, quienes ponen lo mejor D. sí para aumentar sus ingresos y por enD. brindarle lo mejor a sus respectivas familias.
Una D. las miembros es la señora Lilian, ella se dedica a la venta D. prendas D. todo, negocio que le deja buenos ingresos. Comenta que gracias a este trabajo y a su duro e incansable esfuerzo ella logra mantener a su familia y paliar los gastos que diariamente surgen en el seno familiar.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra D. prendas D. todo tipo como ser pantalones, jeans, camisas y demás, para que D. esa forma pueda ampliar el stock D. sus mercaderías.
texts.en:
In the town of Paraguarí, a group of women joined together with the aim of capitalizing their existing businesses and, in some cases, starting new businesses.  They arranged a meeting in order to find out more about the 'Entrepreneurial Women' Program run by Fundación Paraguaya.  They were very interested in the benefits offered to them through the program.  This committee is called 'San Francisco' as its members live in a neighborhood of the same name.  The women are noted for the unity of their group, their energy and their respect for one another.  Through this undertaking, they will strengthen the links between them.  The group are currently in their second loan cycle and have an excellent record.  The group is maD. up of 17 entrepreneurial ladies who do their very best to increase their income and thereby proviD. their respective families with the very best.

One of the members of this group is Lilian.  She sells all kinds of clothing and her business makes her good income.  She tells us that, thanks to her hard work and untiring efforts, she manages to support her family and alleviate the expenses that crop up in the bosom of her family.

Lilian is requesting this loan to buy all kinds of clothing such as pants, jeans, shirts, etc. so that she can expand her stock of merchandise.

loans.use: to buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Adnan

texts.en:
Adnan is a Palestinian young man who he is married and has four sons and one daughter.  He owns a grocery store that is located in a good area and which is the only source of income to the family. Adnan wants to improve his store and purchase more groceries for sale to increase his income. When Adnan gets the loan which is repaid on a monthly basis, he will purchase more groceries and have a better selection of products for sale. This will improve his income and thus the living conditions of his family. Adnan is photographed in his grocery store.


About this loan product:
FATEN offers loan products that are designed to serve borrowers all over Palestine, including some religiously conservative areas. A key tenet of Islam is the prohibition of interest in the lending or accepting of money. This prohibition is based on the belief that money should be seen only as a medium of exchange and that it has no value in itself. FATEN has adapted the terms of this loan to fit the cultural context by attaching a 0% interest rate to the loan. In order to cover its costs, FATEN does charge a servicing fee. The amount you see fundraising includes both the principal loan and the loan servicing fees. As with all Kiva loans, you should expect to have your funds returned to you in accordance with the repayment schedule attached to this loan.
